message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a injury to the median nerve, which supplies the medial 3 digits. Lunate dislocation is the most likely diagnosis as it can cause compression or injury to the median nerve. Fracture of the distal radius can also cause numbness and tingling, but typically does not affect specific digits. Palmar aponeurosis tear and interosseous ligament rupture are less likely causes of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a median nerve injury, which commonly occurs with lunate dislocation. The inability to flex only the lateral 2 digits and tingling in the medial 3 digits along with the history of falling on outstretched hand are consistent with this diagnosis. Fracture of distal radius or palmar aponeurosis tear will not cause numbness in the medial 3 digits. Interosseous ligament rupture will not affect wrist flexion or cause numbness in the fingers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a lunate dislocation, as it is commonly associated with numbness in the medial 3 digits and the inability to flex the lateral 2 digits. Fracture of distal radius may cause wrist pain but not numbness or finger flexion difficulty. Palmar aponeurosis tear and interosseous ligament rupture are less likely to cause these symptoms. X-ray can confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question match those of a lunate dislocation injury. The numbness in the medial 3 digits, inability to flex the lateral 2 digits, and tingling in the medial 3 digits on tapping the anterior portion of the wrist are all indicative of median nerve compression, which can occur in a lunate dislocation injury. An X-ray will help confirm the diagnosis. Fracture of the distal radius may cause wrist pain but not necessarily the numbness and tingling, and the inability to flex the lateral 2 digits. Palmar aponeurosis and interosseous ligament injuries are less common and would not cause the specific symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a lunate dislocation, which can cause numbness in the medial 3 digits and the inability to flex the lateral 2 digits. Fracture of distal radius or palmar aponeurosis tear would not cause this pattern of numbness and flexor weakness. Interosseous ligament rupture would not cause the numbness. The X-ray can confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of numbness in the 3 medial digits and inability to flex the medial 3 digits suggest a median nerve injury. Lunate dislocation is a common injury associated with median nerve injury. Fracture of distal radius, palmar aponeurosis tear, and interosseous ligament rupture are not typically associated with median nerve injury. The X-ray will help confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The numbness in the medial 3 digits and the inability to flex the medial 3 digits suggest a median nerve injury. The most common cause of median nerve injury at the wrist is lunate dislocation. Fracture of the distal radius can cause wrist pain but is less likely to affect the median nerve. Palmar aponeurosis tear and interosseous ligament rupture are not common causes of wrist pain and median nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The numbness in the 3 medial digits, inability to flex the medial digits, and tingling sensation after tapping the wrist all suggest a median nerve injury. The most likely cause of the injury is a lunate dislocation, which can compress the median nerve. Fracture of distal radius can also cause nerve injury, but will not necessarily affect the specific distribution of the median nerve described. Palmar aponeurosis tear and interosseous ligament rupture are not associated with median nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with a lunate dislocation, also known as a perilunate dislocation or dislocation of the carpus. This occurs when a force is applied to the hand, causing the bones of the wrist to displace. Symptoms include pain, numbness, and tingling in certain fingers, as well as difficulty making a fist. X-rays can help confirm the diagnosis. Fracture of the distal radius is also a possibility, but it does not explain the numbness and tingling in specific fingers. Palmar aponeurosis tear and interosseous ligament rupture are less likely given the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests the patient is suffering from a lunate dislocation. This condition can cause numbness and tingling in the 3 medial digits, as well as a loss of flexion in the hand. X-ray findings will confirm the diagnosis. Fracture of the distal radius can cause wrist pain and limited hand movement, but not the numbness and tingling seen in this patient. Palmar aponeurosis tear and interosseous ligament rupture are less likely to cause the specific symptoms described.
